seo.metaTitle: Foot & Ankle Pain Treatment London | PRP & Regenerative Therapy | Dr. SNA
seo.metaDescription: Regenerative foot and ankle clinic in London. PRP, adipose cell therapy, tenotomy, and strength rehab for plantar fasciitis, Achilles tendinopathy, and instability.
seo.h1: Regenerative Foot & Ankle Pain Treatment in London

schema.howPerformed: Using ultrasound or fluoroscopy guidance, we precisely target your injured structure: (1) For plantar fasciitis—PRP or adipose cells injected directly into the torn plantar fascia; (2) For Achilles tendinopathy—PRP injected around and within the thickened tendon, often combined with dry needling to break up scar tissue; (3) For ankle instability—injections into stretched ligaments to stimulate repair; (4) For Morton's neuroma—targeted injections to reduce inflammation around the nerve. Local anesthetic ensures comfort throughout. Procedure takes 30-45 minutes
schema.preparation: Stop anti-inflammatory medications one week before if safe. Stay well-hydrated. Bring supportive footwear—you'll walk out in them. For plantar fascia treatment, stretch your calf beforehand. Avoid barefoot walking for a week after. Come ready to follow a structured rehab plan—foot injuries need patience and persistence
schema.followup: Wear supportive footwear or a boot for 3-5 days. Apply ice for 15 minutes every few hours. Avoid high-impact activities for 2 weeks. Begin prescribed calf stretches and intrinsic foot strengthening at week 2. Gradual return to running/jumping under physiotherapy guidance. Most people return to desk work immediately, physical jobs after 3-5 days. Attend 8-week review to assess healing
schema.outcome: Over 4-8 weeks, that first-step morning pain in your heel fades away. Achilles stiffness improves. Ankle feels more stable. You can walk, run, hike, and stand all day without that nagging ache. The tissue is genuinely stronger and more resilient. Results last 12-18 months. Many patients avoid surgery entirely
schema.medicationRequired: Local anesthetic injection at treatment site. Optional oral pain relief for first 48 hours
schema.treatmentFrequency: 1-3 sessions depending on severity. Plantar fasciitis often responds to single treatment. Chronic Achilles may need 2 sessions spaced 8 weeks apart
schema.adverseOutcome: Soreness for 3-7 days (normal healing response). Bruising on sole of foot possible with plantar fascia injection. Temporary increase in pain for 48 hours. Achilles may feel stiff initially. Very rarely, infection or rupture (we use careful technique)
contraindication: Complete tendon or fascia rupture requiring surgery
Active foot infection or diabetic ulcer
Taking blood thinners without medical clearance
Severe foot deformity requiring surgical correction
